properties.text:
2015

July – 11.-16. Nuremberg, Germany – Please answer this doodle to participate

April/may – In planning - Please answer this doodle to participate

March – 23.-25. Rosenheim, Germany (before Inspiring Conference) - Please answer this doodle to participate. For more information please visit the Wiki Page

There are plenty of code sprints coming up, some of them already have specific dates while others are just in general planning mode. If you'd like to participate in one of them please feel free to fill out a doodle to show your interest.

Practical information
  • The code sprints are open to anyone as long as they can work primarily independently on the core parts of the product. We need help in all kinds of areas, so there's something for anyone being that development, documentation, testing, design, project management etc. However you should get in touch with us if you're interested in joining at neos@typo3.org
  • The work location/accommodation is covered by the Neos code sprint budget from the TYPO3 Association.
  • Travel costs will be reimbursed up to a limit of 200 € per person (exceptions are probably possible, just ask Karsten as our official budget responsible, if you would need a higher budget) – read more

December

In December 2013 a very special code sprint was organized to finalize the release of Neos 1.0. The code sprint was organized by Andreas Förthner and took place at his offices at Netlogix in Nürnberg, Germany. About 15 people attended the sprint and managed to release just in time for the release party scheduled at December 10th 18:00.

  • Wiki Page
  • Release parties

October

In October the team met in Frankfurt, kindly hosted by DE-CIX, who not only sponsored the meeting room but also the accommodation for all participants - thanks a lot! 24 people from 7 countries attended the sprint and worked together on Neos, most of them for the full 5 days of the sprint, resulting in over 150 merged fixes and features. Sebastian prepared a nice video with impressions from the code sprint.

  • Wiki Page

October

Not long after the august code sprint the team met again, this time in Rødby, Denmark. This time we had a special location in form a very large manor, where working location and accommodation was combined. In total 28 participants took part making it the largest code sprint we've had so far. Organized by Aske Ertmann the code sprint welcomed 7 new contributors. Main topics of the sprint was finalizing 1.2, translation of UI and access controls.

  • News Article
  • Wiki Page
  • Unofficial blog posts from Sebastian Helzle, Dmitri Pisarev, Rens Admiraal & Henjo Hoeksma – Part I, Part II, Part III, Part IV & Part V

February

The first code sprint following the release of 1.0 took place in Lübeck, Germany and was organized by Robert Lemke. The focus of the sprint was to improve performance of Neos & Flow. It was a small sprint with 8 participants, however the outcome in terms of gains in performance improvements was big.

  • Wiki Page

March

Not long after the previous sprint the team met again, this time in Rosenheim, Germany. In connection with the Inspiring Conference the team met up before the conference for a few days at Rosenheim University. This was a large code sprint with 19 participants who worked on features for 1.1 and finishing performance improvements.

  • News Article
  • Wiki Page

June

Just before the developers days in Eindhoven, The Netherlands, the team met for a medium sized sprint with 13 participants. Organized by Rens Admiraal the sprint took place the the Technical University of Eindhoven (TU/e). Main topics was finalizing and releasing 1.1, which was released an hour before the developer days kicked off.

  • News Article
  • Wiki Page

August

After the summer holidays the team met up again in the end of august in Kiel, Germany. Organized by Christopher Hlubek the sprint had 13 participants. Main topics for the sprint was to finish features going into 1.2, improving stabilization and discuss various topics.

  • Wiki Page

May

In May 2013 a code sprint took place at punkt.de in Karlsruhe, Germany, where we worked on the work packages and discussed some topics for the stable release. The goals were to find solutions for all the technical questions that were still unclear and to have clearly defined goals for the stable release.

  • Google+ Event Page
  • Wiki Page

We published some blog posts based on discussions during the sprint:

  • Neos and Flow - An update for the team structure
  • Putting Neos technology into usable form

Although people from all over the world are working remotely on TYPO3 Neos, a lot of progress was reached at real-life events. They are not only great for discussions and decisions, but also for developing at light speed.

Apart from working on Neos, code-sprints are also a great opportunity to meet and exchange with old and new friends.

Contributor

Those community members who would like to get involved into the respective project are invited to start contributing code, design, documentation or provide help by other means. No one needs to ask for permission to get involved and start contributing as long as they can identify with our core values and technical principles.

Our more experienced contributors will help new contributors with the first steps in our mailing lists and IRC channels. Anyone who contributes to the project is called a Contributor.

A Contributor …

  • will get credit in a list of contributors for the respective product they worked on.
  • can push changes to Gerrit and review change sets but cannot submit code to master.
  • is - technically - not (yet) part of the Neos team.

Team Member

A team member regularly contributes high-quality code, documentation, design work, or something similar. Existing team members may invite a contributor to join them as a team member through consensus-based decision.

A Team Member ...

  • has deep knowledge of the product.
  • provides recent, recurring, high quality contribution.
  • is eligible for a typo3.org email address.
  • has basically full access and administrative rights to the git repositories, websites, social media accounts etc. like any other member of the team.
  • uses these access rights with great care and responsibility.
  • represents the project responsibly and prefers to solve disputes or disagreements within the team.

A Release Manager schedules and coordinates contributions for a specific release as well as any release announcements and other communication about the release. This position includes the responsibility for a specific major or minor product release, including all of its patch level releases, throughout the lifetime of that maintained version.

The Release Manager is appointed by the Neos team.

For Neos 1.0 the release manager is Sebastian Kurfürst.

For Neos 1.1 the release manager is Christian Müller.

For Neos 1.2 the release manager is Aske Ertmann.

For Neos 2.0 the release manager is Robert Lemke.

A Quality Guardian watches over the overall project consistency and stability. Each commit which changes the behavior of the product (for example introducing a new configuration option, a new feature, breaking backwards compatibility and so on) needs to be acknowledged by a Quality Guardian. There is no technical barrier which would stop Neos team members bypassing a Quality Guardian so this mechanism again is built on trust and responsibility.

The Quality Guardians are chosen by the Neos team and the Quality Manager based on merit and a deep experience and understanding of the product and its vision.

For all packages which are part of the respective product, a package maintainer is appointed. The Package Maintainer is the one to contact before submitting functional changes the first time or if you are in doubt about a certain feature fitting into the package’s concept.

TYPO3 Neos and TYPO3 Flow, originally started by Robert Lemke and Karsten Dambekalns, are built by an ever-growing team of awesome people.

But team members are not the only people who are contributing; many users and other project supporters are helping Neos to grow through a steady stream of high quality contributions.

Feel inspired and invited to join us - even if you only start by fixing a bunch of typos in our documentation!

properties.caption: Contributors and team members alike worked hand in hand during a Neos codesprint in Copenhagen
properties.alternativeText: TYPO3 Neos team members and contributors

properties.text:
We, the team working on Neos and Flow, would like to be able to grow. We want to make it easy for new contributors to join us in building the coolest CMS built on our top notch PHP framework.

We also want to make sure everyone is recognized for their contributions. It should be natural to recognize both active and inactive contributors while we keep the team at a manageable size.

Finally, projects like TYPO3 Neos have plenty of things that need to be organized. Since they've got to be done, we want to give a group of people responsibility for these organizational tasks. To make all of this possible, we have set several groups and roles.

The members of the Neos team base their work, communication and being together on core values like humility, respect, responsibility, and trust.

We try to remove all technical barriers and refrain from creating fine grained rule sets and procedures because we trust team members to use their rights and power responsibly.

Team members adhere to the Code of Conduct of the TYPO3 Project.
We also follow these guiding principles: common sense and good intentions.

There is a dedicated page explaining our core values.

1 A remark about project leadership: The team pretty much manages itself, so the project leader is not the one having the last word on each and every decision. So everyone on the team can be asked and each team member can take decisions. This works, because we value trust and at the same time everyone is humble enough to ask others on the team if in doubt.

Project Leader1

The Project Leader is responsible for the leadership of the project and the product vision. Acting as the user's advocate, this person maintains the high level view on the feature set. A Co-Leader acts as a stand-in for the Project Leader in case of unavailability.

Robert Lemke founded the project and acts as project leader. Karsten Dambekalns is the co-leader.

Quality Manager

The Quality Manager is our chief nitpicker and makes sure that Neos meets our high quality standards. In particular, this person is responsible for coordinating the team of Quality Guardians and overseeing the release process.

Karsten Dambekalns is the quality manager.

Community Contact

The Community Contact lends an ear to the needs of users, existing and potential contributors and solves possible disputes. This position includes staying in touch with the TYPO3 project's community manager and seeking to maintain a healthy community around Neos.

Currently Christian Müller is our community contact.

The Neos Team is led and important tasks are coordinated by a group of team members which form the Coordination Group. You can watch the progress of tasks tackled by the coordination group at their project at forge.typo3.org. The positions in this group may vary depending on the jobs to be done. In the beginning we’ll start with the following:

Public Relations Manager

The Public Relations Manager coordinates the promotion of Neos with the Marketing Team, acts as a press contact, pushes news and takes care of the product website.

Currently Berit Hlubek is our public relations manager.

Treasurer

The treasurer acts as a budget owner and coordinates all efforts regarding funding and raising of funds for the Neos project.

Currently Karsten Dambekalns is our treasurer.

Are you a skilled designer, developer, editor, manager, communicator or have an unusual talent which is missing in our team?

We'll gladly help you to get started and become a contributor by mentoring and sharing our experiences with you.

To get started, start playing with Neos and Flow, then come talk with us via our mailing list or IRC channel. For more hints on how to start contributing to the project, check out our contribution page.

Humility

We all make mistakes. Constructive criticism is always welcome.

Respect

We all have different opinions, different personalities, and different ways to approach problems.

Responsibility

We consider the consequences of our actions, our code, and our communication.

Trust

We trust other team members to make the right decision even when we are absent.

We are members of the Neos team. Each one of us is unique. But we share a set of values that make it fun to work as a team. These are our values. They motivate us and light our internal fire. Our values guide how we communicate and how we make decisions. We are agile. This is who we are.

This is living stuff that describes a living team full of living people. We are alive. We can clarify or adapt anything here to better reflect who we are. This stuff is not rules or procedures. We recorded these thoughts October 2013 at the Neos Codesprint in Frankfurt.

Humility

We love to learn from each other.

Respect 

We are passionate about creating great software.

Responsibility 

We value quality and excellence over mediocre but fast achievements.

Trust

We strive to improve ourselves and the project.

Humility

We discuss vividly, and we do not take it personally.

When I have something to discuss, I bring it up.

I won't take credit for efforts which are attributed to others.

Respect

We disagree, but we do not start flame wars.

When I disagree with you, I will talk with you respectfully.

Responsibility 

Outside the team, we are unified in our communication.

Our communication is consistent.

Trust

We trust each other to speak for the team.

When I present or speak, I speak for the team, not just for my own benefit. I might be a team delegate, and I might look like a team leader to people outside the team, but I recognize that there are no fixed team roles, and I respect my fellow team members.

Humility

We can learn from each other. We make decision processes transparent.

It is okay to reverse the decisions of others. No one can expect to get their way every time.

Respect

We listen to and value each other's arguments and feedback.

Seek the input of others.

Responsibility

We give each other permission to make decisions, and we expect each other to make those decisions quickly and responsibly.

Use common sense instead of fine-grained rules.

Trust

We trust all team members to make decisions. We trust each other to decide with good intentions.

Not everybody needs to be involved to make decisions.

Humility

We might make mistakes, but we take small steps. We can always adjust our course.

It is okay to reverse the decisions of others.

Respect

We celebrate both joint and individual achievements. We respect each team member as a person, not just for the role they are filling right now.

Acknowledge others and give credit where credit is due.

Responsibility

We move forward quickly. We make decision processes transparent.

No official team roles or hierarchy. No bureaucratic procedures.

Trust

We might use informal polls, but we do not have a formal voting process.

Not everybody needs to be involved to make decisions.

• what would you focus on when building a brand new WCMS?
  • what features will be the most important in years to come
  • what would be the optimal user experience for you as an editor or site manager?

properties.source:
As a client using TYPO3, have you ever had the feeling it was too difficult to give us feedback on our products?
This is for you.

properties.title: Clients of TYPO3 get to influence development directly

properties.text:
One of the great things about being a client of an open source community-based product is that you get to influence the feature-set and the entire development of the software you depend on directly.

Over the years, an abundance of client feedback has transformed TYPO3 CMS. This process naturally goes on.

properties.title: Your chance to impact the CMS of the future

properties.text:
As the feature set of the first version of Neos is virtually fixed, we can now focus on planning ahead - beyond the 1.0 release.

TYPO3 Neos is already being used for real projects - but to use it for larger, complex solutions, we need to plan ahead into a future of a relatively unknown territory. For that to work well, we are collecting input from various sources:

  • ...our strong development community
  • ...the business leaders of TYPO3 agencies
  • ...first-hand feedback coming from all the daily client contact we have on the Neos team
  • ...outside experts beyond the TYPO3 community are being consulted to challenge our thoughts

Now is the time to gather a group of experienced clients to iteratively influence our thinking and planning.

We have already made contact to the first major clients interested in taking part in the follow-group, giving continuous feedback on Neos development.


But we need about 3-5 more enterprise-level clients who manage large, complex web projects.

As part of the follow-group this is what will happen:

  • When we have major new overall plans, features or UI's - we send it to you and ask for your feedback.
  • Giving feedback is quick: Via Skype or Google hangout, we quickly brief you on the concept or feature up for discussion. You tell us what you think about it - and what you believe the implications of the changes would be to you, your content editors or your developers.
  • The feedback is then discussed on the team and translated into changes.
  • If you like and prefer another level of openness, we can feature your organization, build cases together and help tell your stories - it's entirely up to you.

• Direct influence on development will help make sure you get a highly usable WCMS platform in the future.
  • Access to expert web developers, architects and UX'ers that can give advice on when and how to start using Neos and Flow.
  • Networking with other clients with shared interests in WCMS.
  • If you're interested, just mail rasmus[at]typo3.org and tell us about your organization and how you worked with CMSes before.

If you're interested, just mail rasmus[at]typo3.org and tell us about your organization and how you worked with CMSes before.

We're always looking for new contributors. If you can help in one of the following areas, please get in touch with us!

  • Code
  • Testing
  • Usability
  • Documentation
  • Feature ideas
  • Anything else useful for TYPO3 Neos

We're looking forward to hearing from you!

Offer contribution

Want to offer your contribution? Please get in touch with us on mailing lists or IRC (irc.freenode.net, channel #typo3-flow or #typo3-neos) so we can find someone to mentor your contribution.

These people are members of the release team:

  • the Release Manager of each maintained release branch
  • the Team Leader
  • the Quality Manager

The Release team has these responsibilities:

  • Define and maintain the release process.
  • Decide which features match the product vision.
  • Plan and execute security releases with the Security Team.

There are four phases in the release process:

  1. Communication
  2. Preparation
  3. Release
  4. Finalization

News articles and other announcements should be written in the Communication phase, and published in the Finalization phase.

The preparation phase deals with any technical steps that need to be done before running the Jenkins release job, such as creating any new branches in git. Then, the Jenkins release job does the heavy lifting to tag the release, generate tarballs, push them to SourceForge, and a variety of other tasks that go into doing a release.

The Release Manager should be able to access the latest version of our Release Process document (All team members should have access to the latest version of this document which is currently stored in Google Drive.).

This page provides an overview of how we approach releases. This is a reference document for anyone interested in our releases, but is especially useful to help release managers understand their role in this process. The Release Lifecycle is managed by the Release Manager who is a member of the Release Team. The Release Team defines the Release Process. Each of these topics is described here.
Note: Both Neos and Flow have the same release lifecyle and release process. As both projects are managed by the same team, the release manager role works the same for both projects. Essentially, the release team includes release managers from both products instead of having a separate "team" for each.

There are two kinds of releases for Flow and Neos (Releases should use semantic versioning semver.org):

  • A new release is a release on a new release branch such as 2.0 or 2.1. (Semver.org: Major and Minor level versions)
  • A bugfix release is a release on an existing release branch such as 2.0.5. (Semver.org: Patch-level version)

In general, this is how we decide when to do a new release:

  • Release as soon as one or more major features is complete, including documentation.
  • Release within half a year after the last release, even if no major features have been completed.

Minor features can be included/merged in any new release but not for a bugfix release. Documentation for these features should be included.

We want bugfix releases to be automatic (if possible) or at least, they should happen frequently. The release manager is responsible for making sure these bugfix releases happen frequently, as required.

We only support, with bugfix releases, the latest release branch and one release previous to the latest release branch. However we try to make migrating from release to release as smooth as possible. Depending on the severity, we can also release security bugfix releases for older releases, but don't guarantee that we will.

A Release Manager is responsible for a release branch that includes a specific new release and all of its bugfix releases (i.e. The Release Manager for 2.0 is responsible for 2.0.1, but not 2.1). The Release Manager is responsible, throughout the maintenance lifetime of their specific release branch, for the following things:

  • Schedule and coordinate contributions for a specific release branch and all of its bugfix releases.
  • Prevent feature creep within the release branch by having a vision of what features can or should be included in the release.
    • The release manager has the final say on which changes can be included in the release.
  • Make sure that any major features are included in release notes before the feature is merged into the release.
  • Collaborate with the community contact and public relations manager to:
    • communicate the timeline and release branch vision,
    • write and distribute release announcements, and
    • other release specific communication.
  • Be available to answer questions about whether or not to include a change in the release branch.
  • Make sure releases happen, including the release branch's new release and all bugfix releases (See "The Release Process" below).

Release Date: December 10, 2013
TYPO3 Neos 1.0 is the first stable release and happened right before a series of release parties all over the world on December 10th.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: December 3, 2013
TYPO3 Neos Beta 2 brought us even closer to the countdown of the final release on December 10th. This release included many improvements for making it possible for the integrator to be in control of the output from Neos. Besides that it included many bug fixes and stability improvements as well as the possibility to configure whether or not having pages ending with .html.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: December 13, 2013
TYPO3 Neos 1.0.1 is the first patch level release of the 1.0 branch. It was released three days after the first stable release and includes several bugfixes and minor improvments, mainly within the TYPO3.Neos package and inside the demo page.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: March 3, 2014
The release of TYPO3 Neos 1.0.2 delivers several bugfixes mainly within the package TYPO3.Neos as well as some fixes for TYPO3.TYPO3CR and some minor features.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: November 12, 2013
TYPO3 Neos beta 1 marked the countdown to the final release on December 10th. This release included most of the remaining features that will go into 1.0. We especially emphasized on getting all breaking changes in to make it as easy as possible to update from the beta to the final release. It included some new features like node references, allowing site root to contain content, customizable output, easier creation of content elements as well as various improvements.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: November 14, 2014
The third release of Neos focuses on adding translation support, improving the editor experience and implementing many new features. 92 new features, 265 tasks and 232 bugfixes make up the progress since the release of 1.1. 

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: November 26, 2014
The second beta release includes two important fixes that solves issues with moving nodes and linking to nodes/assets in inline editing. Additionally contains some UI improvements, minor additions and bugfixes.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: December 11, 2014
This release includes a fix for a regression introduced with Flow 2.2.1 that affected file uploads in the media module. On top of that it contains more fixes that have been merged since version 1.1.1.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.
Additionally a bunch of teasers can be found here.

Release Date: December 03, 2014
The third beta release includes three important fixes that makes it compatible with PHP 5.3 again, kickstarting new sites and exporting sites. Additionally contains some UI improvements, minor additions and bugfixes.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: January 2, 2015
This release contains some improvements and fixes several issues including an issue the new link editor, an issue with site import and an issue with moving of nodes.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: February 5, 2015
This release fixes several issues including the "Raw content" editing mode and 25 other issues as well as some minor improvements.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: April 11, 2014
After 265 commits, thousands of lines of code changed and 2 code sprints, the first beta version of Neos 1.1 is released. A total number of 30 contributors, dedicated team members and a supportive community made this release possible.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: June 19, 2014
For the 1.1 release of TYPO3 Neos, we wanted to build a strong foundation for the major features that we are preparing for future releases. As such, we focused on stability and performance improvements.

Read the announcement for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: April 15, 2014
TYPO3 Neos 1.1 Beta 2 is the second beta release of the upcoming 1.1 version.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: May 27, 2014
TYPO3 Neos 1.1 Beta 3 is the second beta release of the upcoming 1.1 version.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: August 26, 2014
The first bugfix release of the 1.1 branch includes a lot of bug fixes mainly to content editing. It was released during a Neos Code Sprint in Kiel, together with TYPO3 Flow 2.2.1.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: September 2, 2014
This release includes a fix for a regression introduced with Flow 2.2.1 that affected file uploads in the media module. On top of that it contains more fixes that have been merged since version 1.1.1.

Read the detailed list of changes in the changelog.

Release Date: October 22, 2013
TYPO3 Neos Alpha 6 contained lots of improvements, where most of them were incorporated during the code sprint at DE-CIX in Frankfurt. Main highlights were improved content editing, Plugin Views, features in TypoScript, a new demo site, improved security and lots of bugfixes and stability improvements.

Read on for more information and a detailed list of changes in the release notes.

Release Date: October 30, 2013
TYPO3 Neos Alpha 7 contained a couple of improvements, as being listed in the release notes. This was the last Alpha release of TYPO3 Neos.

Release Date: August 7, 2013
TYPO3 Neos Alpha 5 featured lots of smaller improvements, as being listed in the release notes.

Release Date: July 7, 2013
TYPO3 Neos Alpha 4 featured lots of great improvements, as being listed in the release notes.

Release Date: February 16, 2013
Alpha 3 concentrated on stabilizing the content editing and UI of Neos. Additionally some groundwork for future features was put into place. All changes since alpha 2 are listed in the changelog.

Release Date: December 19, 2012
Read the changes since alpha 1 to be informed about this release.

Release Date: October 5, 2012
The first Alpha of TYPO3 Neos was presented and released at the European T3CON 2012 in Stuttgart.

To update an existing installation to the latest patch release you can update the packages this way:

composer update --no-dev "typo3/*"
# Remember to flush the caches afterwards
./flow flow:cache:flush --force
./flow doctrine:migrate

By using composer, you can switch to the most recent master, in order to test the latest changes:

cd /installation-root/
# update requested version numbers
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos:dev-master"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-nodetypes:dev-master"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neosdemotypo3org:dev-master"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-kickstarter:dev-master"
composer require --no-update "typo3/buildessentials:dev-master"
# actually update the packages
composer update
# Remember to flush the caches afterwards
./flow flow:cache:flush --force
./flow doctrine:migrate

Server Environment

Not surprisingly, you'll need a web server for running TYPO3 Neos. We recommend Apache or nginx (though IIS and others work too – we just haven't really tested them). Please make sure that the mod_rewrite module is enabled.

TYPO3 Neos requires a database supported by Doctrine DBAL.

PHP

Make sure you have PHP 5.3.2 or later available on your web server. Make sure your PHP CLI binary is the same version! If available, you should use PHP 5.6 as it improves performance compared to earlier versions. Generally, a newer PHP version is better.

The default settings and extensions of the PHP distribution should work fine, but it doesn't hurt checking if the PHP modules mbstring, tokenizer and pdo_mysql are enabled, especially if you compiled PHP yourself. You really should (not only because of TYPO3 Neos) turn off magic quotes in your php.ini (magic_quotes_gpc = off).

Make sure the PHP functions system(), shell_exec(), escapeshellcmd() and escapeshellarg() are not disabled in you PHP installation. They are required for the system to run.

For more information on the system requirements check the relevant part of the TYPO3 Flow documentation.

This page has instructions to install Neos with composer, which downloads Neos itself. If you don't want to use composer, then download an archive inxstead. After having installed either way, continue to set up Neos as explained further down.

Note: If you want to learn more about which versions we support, and how we decide when to do a new release, please see our All about Releases page.

• Set up a virtual host inside your apache.conf, and then restart apache:
    NameVirtualHost *:80 # if needed

    <VirtualHost *:80>
        DocumentRoot "/your/htdocs/TYPO3-Neos-1.2/Web/"
        # skip the following line for development
        SetEnv FLOW_CONTEXT Production
        ServerName neos.demo
    </VirtualHost>
  • Add an entry to /etc/hosts:
    127.0.0.1 neos.demo
  • Go to http://neos.demo/setup and follow the on-screen instructions!
Continue with the setup step now.

Alternatively install the 1.2 beta:

php /path/to/composer.phar create-project -s beta typo3/neos-base-distribution TYPO3-Neos-1.2

  • 1.2.0 Changelog & release notes

properties.text:
• 1.1.2 Changelog
  • 1.1.1 Changelog
  • 1.1.0 Changelog & release notes

Installing Neos from an archive is convenient if you just want to try Neos and for the first steps. If you want to dive deeper into Neos and create a real site with it, we recommend using the installation via composer, instead.

First download the archive for the Neos version you want to install. Then unpack the archive to your webserver document root directory and continue with the setup.

First install composer like this:

curl -s https://getcomposer.org/installer | php

Then go to your webserver document root directory and download the Neos base distribution with all the dependencies:

cd /your/htdocs/
php /path/to/composer.phar create-project --no-dev typo3/neos-base-distribution TYPO3-Neos-1.2

By using composer, you can update an existing installation to the a specific version, without having to create a new project:

cd /installation-root/

# Remove the following line from composer.json (if present)
"minimum-stability": "dev",

# Update the composer.json file
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos:1.2.*"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-nodetypes:1.2.*"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neosdemotypo3org:1.2.*"
composer require --no-update "typo3/neos-kickstarter:1.2.*"
composer require --no-update "typo3/flow:2.3.*"
composer require --no-update "doctrine/migrations:@dev"

# Update the packages
composer update

# Remember to flush the caches afterwards
./flow flow:cache:flush --force
./flow doctrine:migrate
./flow node:migrate 20140708120530 --confirmation TRUE
./flow node:migrate 20140326143834
./flow node:migrate 20140930125621
./flow node:repair

# If you're migrating from the 1.2-dev branch you might need these
./flow node:migrate 20140516221523
./flow node:migrate 20140723115900
./flow node:migrate 20141210114800
See the release notes for a list of breaking changes

For further information on what changed please take a look at the release notes.

There are different ways of installing TYPO3 Neos. For having a first look at the CMS we provide an archive which you can easily download. If you want to dive deeper and start with your Neos project we recommend using composer instead.

In only few years from now, the world will have entirely new cities. Cities whose development has not even started. Cities that can draw from all we know about livability and functionality. The same goes for websites. Major websites will be built with the tools we’re constructing today. But we don't know how they will be like. Just think of how different sites were 3 years ago.

For both cities and websites, one basic rule counts: Things are constantly changing and can never be fully anticipated.

The inspiration from urban planning permeates our UX master plan, giving us crucial guidelines for structuring everything we know  - and making room for all the future change we don’t know.

In 2017, Neos will have been in use for years as a trusted tool to build and maintain complex websites. Many extensions were added and ideas we cannot imagine today will have been added to the software.

Yet, today we need to decide on major parts of the experience and the interface. If everything is added on an ad hoc basis - because it just feels right to put a button here and a menu there - you would end up with slums of the interface.

We've planned the Neos backend like you plan cities - with lots of room for change. Regardless of you being an integrator, a developer, a content editor or a site manager, the overall experience of using Neos provides for a productive life inside the interface.

We’ve put emphasis on concepts, in line with the feature set, that will provide for great personalization of both the backend workflow and the web experience that publishers will be able to deliver. The principles we've chosen can guide later alterations to the interface.

1. Create boundaries: Clearly separate different kinds of components to make users know where to look.
  2. Thinking is King: It’s your thinking that determines the web experience for your users, not the CMS.
  3. Distribute capacity: Provide power when needed.
  4. Simulate before publishing: Experience what your users will experience.
  5. Plan for change: Make the interface adaptable to reorganizing.

2. Thinking is King

It’s your thinking that determines the web experience for your users, not the CMS

1. Create boundaries

Clearly seperate different kinds of components to make users know where to look

When we looked at the city as an analogy for websites, we looked for boundaries to help us structure the Neos backend. In cities, there’s a very hard boundary between private and public. With that thinking we made a plan for where things belong.

A street is not a home. You drive fast on highways, not on the sidewalks. Likewise, we’ve planned the backend experience to give everything a natural home in the interface and in workflows. A module is in the menu, a node of every type is in the new Navigate menu, meta-data is in the Inspector -  and you edit your content seamlessly in the content itself.

These major parts will function as our hard boundaries preventing flooding of the interface. Everything logically structured to make sure developers will know where to put new components - making users know where to find everything.

When planning a city, you need to think. Often, content management systems will tell you that they’ve done all the thinking for you.

In Neos, you’ll be able to build great websites with a CMS that doesn't impose a certain process or a particular business logic. Neos doesn’t compete with other software that makes it super-easy to build a quick blog or a photo gallery. It is meant for more complex solutions.

Yet at the same time, we use UI design principles from the world of easy-to-use web experiences. It’ll be up to you to decide how you work with it.

You can build a web application first, then later decide to use Neos as a thin layer of content editing on top - or the other way around. The interface must facilitate such variation of use.

3. Distribute capacity

Provide power when needed

The distribution of power in a city makes sure that everyone gets what they need. You don’t power a shed in the way you power a nuclear plant. The ultra-simple editing makes editors center their attention on content.

If you need to add SEO data next to the content, Neos has an inspector that opens up for that kind of functionality. Just a bit more power, one step at a time... If you need more, the inspector will be expandable to the full backend screen providing the user with all the options.

That’s not enough? Create custom backend modules. And if even that's not enough, underlying Neos, we have Flow - a first-class web framework that enables you to build web applications that integrate with your other systems.

We don’t get in your way. We just provide open, flexible, powerful tools and a mindset of how to work with them. Everything connected in interfaces that don't interfere with the process of your business.

4. Simulate before delivering

Experience what your users will experience

With Neos, you will be able to view and preview your content in different ways. Switch to fullscreen mode to experience exactly what your users will experience. If your designer is not finished with the design, you can also make content editors start working with content in wireframe mode and apply templates later.

If you want editors to preview how SEO metadata for a page will appear in a Google search, you should be able to extend the preview for the editor. Same goes for mobile preview, tablet or any other preview you need. The longer-term plan is to collect all these views in one View menu.

5. Plan for change

Make the interface adaptable to reorganizing

Cities change constantly - and websites do the same. We cannot fully predict how the web will work in the years to come. We're working hard to make the interface and the frontend development of the backend as flexible as possible.

As everything is logically structured in the backend, later rearrangements of the interface will be a lot easier.

The Neos team is putting together all the generic design interface specifications into a single document that will allow future designers and developers achieve a consistent user experience across any kind of plugin or module.

If you are an experienced application interface designer, this is therefore a perfect time to help out. Write to Rasmus (rasmus[at]typo3[dot]org) if you want to get in touch.

Aske Ertmann & Rasmus Skjoldan

We strive for a quarterly release cycle of TYPO3 Neos. The team will focus on key features for each release that will be prioritized from users feedback and actual project needs.

This page shall give an overview about the upcoming areas we will work on.

After years of development we need time off, so we will go into REST.

Work on a more REST-like interface for Neos has already been started, and will be continued shortly after the 1.0 release. We aim for a solid and generic interface to access the content repository.

We aim for being able to transfer TYPO3 CMS pages and the standard Content Elements like Text or Image. Furthermore, the conversion process should be adjustable to be usable for  Flexible Content Elements or custom content.

We'd like to add a page cache to Neos, so that it can be used without Varnish.

Furthermore, we have lots of ideas on how we can improve performance, so that will definitely be a focus in the future.

From the very beginning, Neos rendering has been built to allow for rendering only parts of a web page. However, we do not expose this functionality to the user yet.

By allowing partial rendering from the outside, Neos  – in combination with Edge Side Includes and Varnish  – will allow to build highly customized experiences without sacrificing performance.

While we are able to work with multiple content appearances right from the start, we did not tackle customized content for each channel yet. We'd especially like to allow arbitrary conditions to be used in rendering; i.e. changing a header image depending on the current weather or the user's geographical location.

As already stated, Neos is using annotations to access the content on a page. We do so using VIE and CreateJS.

In the upcoming period we will see how to collaborate on decoupled content management with CreateJS, and how we can add extra editors to Neos to link semantic metadata to content with Annotate.js.

TYPO3 Neos cannot be built without participation of many dedicated community members – we need your help to implement your favourite feature.

Just get in touch with us so we can bring you up to speed.

We have created the TYPO3 Expose package to be an extensible base package for listing and editing arbitrary records, be it content in Neos or arbitrary domain objects of any Flow application.

While the package is roughly working, there are still lots of details in terms of user interaction that need to be fixed.

We know that content management of today is different than it was a few years ago. Dealing with high load, distributed services is very common. In TYPO3 Neos, we want to make our export/import functionality more versatile to use and also create a service that allows synchronization of content across different web sites.

Because of its robust foundations, clean abstraction layers and the use of universally unique identifiers (UUIDs), this is a lot easier to implement than with classical web applications.

In bigger projects, it is important to define fine-grained access rules on who is allowed to see and edit which parts of the website. We would like to add permissions in TYPO3CR on the page and document level.

Furthermore, we'd like to provide a frontend login working out of the box, allowing to put parts of the website behind a login.

Because of the content-first approach of Neos, you'll end up with lots of node types, where only very few make sense globally.

That's why we'd like to make it configurable where a node type is allowed to be placed.

properties.title: Multi-language support in TYPO3CR and User Interface

properties.text:
Handling multiple languages and areas with proper fallback support is a key feature of every advanced CMS. While we thought about multi-language features right from the first concept, it is not implemented in TYPO3CR yet and the User Interface. We will close this gap and support multiple languages and locales.

Other than that, the user interface should also be localized, both the backend as well as the content editing experience. This is rather straight-forward, as TYPO3 Flow already has a sophisticated localization system in place which just has to be used.

There are still some open tasks regarding the structure and test coverage of our JavaScript code base – we want to achieve the same level of perfection we put into the Flow and Neos PHP code.

Additionally, now that composer forms the foundation of package management, the foundation is laid to separate Neos into different packages for different concerns. Ideally, every backend module should become its own package to be easily maintainable.

The Neos team is improving the master plan of the Neos user experience while agencies all over the world are slowly beginning to do their own web sites using the alpha version of Neos. We have in Neos a beautiful baby - but it still needs to be taught manners and raised well.

So, the team has been asking itself the simple question: How will large labyrinthine organizations work with web sites in 2017? 

We’re also asking leading user experience and CMS experts from around the world the same question, getting them to challenge our thoughts.

…Plus, we’d love to hear the answers of everyone in the community!

properties.title: How do you think enterprises will build and maintain their complex sites in 2017?

properties.text:
If you’d like to take part in this discussion, please join the Neos forum and share your thoughts. The input we get will directly influence the way we plan future functionality of Neos.

We’ll share some of the inspirational thoughts that will appear throughout the process coming from both the TYPO3 community and outsiders.

properties.caption: Neos team discussing the structuring of the general user experience at the May '13 code sprint
properties.title: Untitled

properties.text:
The master plan of the first production-ready versions of Neos is pretty set by now.

But as Neos is a CMS that will work especially well for the larger, more complex solutions, we’re looking for all the help we can get in prioritizing future features and how we structure the user interface to handle e.g. complex localization or digital asset management.

Read on if you’d like to get insight into the inner workings of the user experience plan.

The Neos team is putting together all the generic design interface specifications into a single document that will allow future designers and developers achieve a consistent user experience across any kind of plugin or module.

If you are an experienced application interface designer, this is therefore a perfect time to help out.

Write to Rasmus (rasmus[at]typo3[dot] org) if you want to get in touch.

TYPO3 Association

6340 Baar
Switzerland

The TYPO3 Association is committed to user privacy. For statistical reasons we collect the following technical data:

  • type of browser
  • type of operating system
  • referrer Url
  • time and date of the use of the website
  • your IP address

This data is collected anonymously and will be kept separately from private user data, you might have to give us at this Website.
We might use cookies to keep your session active. A cookie is a little textfile, that is stored from your browser on your system. We do not use cookies for personal data recognition.

In some cases we need to collect your private user data, to process certain information on this website This data will not be give to any other third party without your explicit written notice.

In some cases we might be forced to give the data to official government agencies.
In case you want to know what data we collect on our servers, feel free to send us an e-mail to t3o [at] typo3 . org

properties.title: Predicting and shaping the future of web content management

properties.text:
What kind of CMS tools and processes will be important in 4 years from now? How can we plan our software today so that it is highly relevant in years to come? Such questions are naturally essential to the planning of a new CMS, based on our experience of the +500.000 site strong TYPO3 CMS.

Here, experts like content strategist, Karen McGrane, vendor-neutral client advisors like Janus Boye and Perttu Tolvanen of North Patrol - as well as large CMS clients such as the Danish Broadcasting Corporation - have all given us their views on the future of content management.

On our way to the 1.0 release of TYPO3 Neos, the team building the open source CMS realized we had to take planning much further. We couldn't just focus on getting 1.0 ready.

That simple realization made us start curating this collection of forecasts. About how the web will be built in 2017.

properties.title: Hi future! How will the web be built in 2017?

properties.text:
We have spent a good deal of time asking leading experts in the field about how they see the future of WCMS. Mixing their great experience and knowledge with our own thoughts on how the WCMS field is changing, we now can better plan beyond our first production-ready release of TYPO3 Neos.

In company with this goal, we also wanted to tell the story about how much change is going on in the CMS world.

properties.source: <iframe src="http://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/24491044?rel=0" width="340" height="290" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" style="border:1px solid #CCC;border-width:1px 1px 0;margin-bottom:5px" allowfullscreen> </iframe>

properties.text:
Karen McGrane, Janus Boye, Alain Veuve, Perttu Tolvanen, Boris Kraft, Kian Gould, Martin Goldbach Olsen, Jacob Floyd, Mikkel Staunsholm, Olivier Dobberkau, Daniel Hinderink, Christian Badse, Robert Lemke, Jan-Erik Revsbech, Sebastian Kurfuerst, Anders Bendix Kiel, Christian Nilson, Rasmus Skjoldan

(Please note that all statements have kindly been given to us specifically for this collection.)

Apart from this collection of thoughts on the future, many things are going on in the continuous planning of TYPO3 Neos. We're quite far in establishing a client follow-group that will help us make sure that we are building a tool for real client needs and not just our own itches. We have been conducting interviews, workshops and meetings with leading experts - among others with Head of User Research at the UK Government Digital Service, Leisa Reichelt, Yat Hui of Urban Beings and Information Architects Inc.

Our development releases also showed a lot of the technical progress taking place - and the newly revised user interface, guided by our user experience master plan. With the release of the first production-ready version we also experience the launch of bigger real-life projects.

We hope many people will share and debate what some of the implications of these predictions may be. On Twitter using #TYPO3Neos or on the TYPO3 Neos forum and mailing list.

Questions about the 2017 WCM Forecast can be sent to TYPO3 Neos designer, Rasmus Skjoldan at rasmus[at]typo3.org.

TYPO3 Neos 1.0 and 1.1 are only the beginning of next-generation content management. We're already preparing future releases that will make your experience even better. To stay updated about new releases, please subscribe to our announcement newsletter.

The following introduction video to TYPO3 Neos shows you how quick and easy it is to edit content. Part of the video is a demonstration on how to create pages, edit texts and insert and crop images as well as how publishing content changes works.

You can choose between an english and a german version of the screencast.

Can’t wait to try TYPO3 Neos but don’t want to spend time on installing it? Take a free test drive with a pre-installed version and experience the new feel of content editing:

  • Launchr offers a hosted TYPO3 Neos for testing purposes for free. Just sign-up and take off with Neos.
  • A 30-day trial hosting with a pre-installed Neos is offered by Mittwald.
  • Codecoon offers an one-click TYPO3 Neos Installer for Mac and Windows and a free TYPO3 Neos hosting for demo purposes.

If your company is also offering a test environment for TYPO3 Neos and you would like to be listed here, please get in touch with us.

Here, you'll find some step-by-step instructions on how to learn Neos.

We plan to greatly extend this section in the future.

You can find the TYPO3 Neos Demo Site inside the Packages/Sites/TYPO3.NeosDemoTypo3Org folder of your Neos distribution.

The Neos Demo Site follows all best-practices for TYPO3 Neos, so we suggest that you analyze and modify it.

Now, it's time to check out the Neos Documentation, most specifically:

  • The Getting Started guide explains the installation and the basics of the Neos UI.
  • The Neos Integrator Cookbook contains short solutions to many common requirements.
  • The Neos Integrator Guide contains full explanations of TYPO3CR, TypoScript and the whole rendering process.

We need your help expanding the documentation! It is currently stored inside the Neos Git Repository; so you can push your suggested changes to review.typo3.org as usual.

If you need help in setting up everything you need, get in touch with the team and we can help you out.
Head over to the Download page for the installation instructions. As soon as you have Neos installed and ran the setup tool, you will have the Neos Demo Site available to play with.

properties.title: How can I use the semantic features in Neos? I can't find any hint in the user interface or editor.

properties.text:
Neos is semantic ready, as it is possible to create any markup you'd like inside your content element. Thus, creating content elements which adhere to microformats, RDFa or schema.org is a breeze.

Furthermore, CreateJS allows for future UI integration of semantic editing features. For details have a look at Rens' and Henri's presentation slides about CreateJS and Neos from T3CON12, or watch the recorded presentation.
We collected questions regarding installation and usage of TYPO3 Neos. Can't find your question on this page? Feel free to send us a message and we will help you out and add the question here.

Yes, Neos has a built-in cache system since version 1.1. The content cache stores rendered content and was designed for flexible use even in complex websites

We recommend to use a caching proxy like Varnish in front of TYPO3 Neos for high traffic sites.

properties.title: Where can I find merchandise for Neos?

properties.text: There will be an official shop with several different products.

properties.title: What is the official hash tag for Neos?

properties.text: The hash tag we use for Neos and where we will also look for questions and other input is: #TYPO3Neos.

properties.title: Why can't Neos do this or that?

properties.text:
First off, we want to do everything right from the start. The idea is that whenever we release a feature it will be as bulletproof as humanly possible.

This ideal of course somewhat limits the amount of features we can put out at a time, but we put quality over quantity.

Furthermore, due to the big flexibility of Neos and Flow, it’s often possible to create new features as separate packages – so we need your help to build the features you need. If you feel a feature is missing and you’d like to build it, please get in touch with the team and we can provide you some guidance.

properties.title: Can I import my website from TYPO3 CMS?

properties.text:
We need to distinguish between content import and template/extension import.

Template/Extension import is not possible, and will never be. However, if you use Extbase and Fluid in TYPO3 CMS already, it will be easier for you to port this code to Neos.

Content import is currently not possible.

However, while we do not have content import ready as of today, we are already experimenting with different approaches of a content migration process and think that pages and the standard TYPO3 CMS content elements like Text or Image will be importable in the future. Additionally, we’ll make sure that the conversion process is extensible, so you can adjust it if you use special FCEs or the like.

You can download our TYPO3 Neos fact sheet. If you need a print optimized version just contact us.

Detailed information for the promotion of TYPO3 Neos at conferences and fairs will follow.
Download Neos Flyer [pdf | 598 kb]

TYPO3 Neos enables you to export and import website content. You can easily move content between development, staging and production.

Additionally, Neos is deployable through Surf – the standard deployment solution of  TYPO3. Surf makes changes to functionality in your projects reproducible and highly reliable.

Requirements will change during the lifecycle of your product. This is why we put a lot of effort into making TYPO3 Neos as easily extendable as possible.

For more advanced use-cases you can use the power of the TYPO3 Flow application framework to add new functionality.

properties.title: What do others say about Neos

properties.text: Deane Barker from gadgetopia.com shares his thoughts about our new CMS after a demonstration of TYPO3 Neos:
Karen McGrane, the author of Content Strategy for Mobile, gives her impression of TYPO3 Neos:

TYPO3 Neos is the next-generation open source content management system made by the TYPO3 community. Neos is based on the PHP framework TYPO3 Flow.

From now on, the TYPO3 community provides two different CMS products: TYPO3 CMS and TYPO3 Neos. The popular TYPO3 CMS will continue to be developed, upgraded and enhanced. TYPO3 CMS and TYPO3 Neos have different qualities. For some projects, TYPO3 CMS might be the best choice while for others, Neos is able to show its strength. 

You should choose between TYPO3 CMS and TYPO3 Neos based on your project and workflow needs. We will continue making it as easy as possible to understand our products and produce the information needed to choose wisely between them.
Read full release notes of the current release
Download TYPO3 Neos 1.2

TYPO3 Neos 1.2

Ubiquitous Content just arrived. TYPO3 Neos 1.2 has been released.

The most basic way of editing content in Neos is available by just clicking what you want to change, working out the changes and pressing the publish button. Then your changes are live. You will see the content changes in the actual design. 

If you need to edit SEO data next to the content, Neos provides an inspector for that.

If you need more, the inspector will be expandable to the full screen providing the user with all property options.

That’s not enough? Create custom backend modules.

And if even that is not enough, underlying Neos, we have Flow – a first-class web application framework which will enable you to build applications that can be integrated with your other systems.

Neos will blend in seamlessly with your website so you as an editor don't have to re-think in order to edit your content. It is our philosophy to reduce the amount of cognitive load to make editing content fun again.

You don‘t need training to edit content in Neos – you already know how to do it. You just click on the part you want to edit – and start. But since publishing projects have very different authoring needs, there is no only way of editing content in Neos.

Either use the full In-Place editing or use what we call Raw Content editing. Raw Content is like having a distraction-free authoring application right inside your CMS – where all the templates are stripped away.

Raw Content mode also makes reusing content across channels more efficient because editors don't spend time perfecting content to match the template. Instead they can focus on the pure words and images while working with a tailored authoring interface.

The Preview Central is where you build your preview templates. If you want your editors to always check three different representations of their content before publishing, then this is easily done in Neos.  

The Preview Central is right next to your editing modes in TYPO3 Neos. You can quickly switch back and forth between editing and previewing.

When you create responsive websites, your CMS should naturally aid you by being responsive as well.

Your websites will load faster, feel more fluid and generate a better user experience than websites built with any other CMS on the market.

Since the advanced content editing mechanisms in TYPO3 Neos work together with your website you can change your contents directly within a responsive viewport – getting immediate results and reducing the time of testing your contents on different devices.

Apart from that TYPO3 Neos does not force you to build your website in a special way. Just create your templates - Neos will take care of the rest.

Since TYPO3 Flow is cloud-ready, so is TYPO3 Neos. TYPO3 Neos scales with your business and your demands. You plan an intense marketing campaign? Simply add as many servers as needed to your environment.

This is all made possible with TYPO3 Surf, enabling zero-downtime deployment and making it easy to set up identical servers.

Outrun the competition using TYPO3 Neos' advanced semantic features.

With TYPO3 Neos, creating custom content elements is a breeze - with whatever markup you need. So go ahead and embed RDFa, Microformats or schema.org attributes inside your templates - whatever fits best to your use-case.

properties.title: Standing on the shoulders of a giant

properties.text:
The TYPO3 community provides two different CMS products: TYPO3 CMS and TYPO3 Neos.


We took the experience of more than 500.000 websites built in TYPO3 CMS and used our collective expertise to make a new kind of CMS.

Being built upon the most advanced PHP framework to date – TYPO3 Flow – makes your websites ready for whatever the future holds for you.

TYPO3 Flow is secure by default, keeping your developers focussed on their main task - building your application - without having to worry about low level implementations.

The „code once - run everywhere“ approach of TYPO3 Flow makes the move from the application to the website very simple.

Whether you start with your website and build the applications from there or you have your application and need content management added to it – TYPO3 Neos and TYPO3 Flow got your back.

properties.source:
• TYPO3 Neos 1.0

    Changing the world of web content management. TYPO3 Neos 1.0 has been released.

properties.text:
Show Cases

Are you curious who is already working with TYPO3 Neos? Looking for a list of references for inspiration or as an argument for your next project?
We tried to identify most projects out there to give you an overview what is possible with Neos and - of course - to show you: It's time to start your own project now because Neos is ready for it.

We divided the list into two categories: "Customer" and "Agency/Usergroup" to differentiate the target groups, because customer projects are mostly requirement driven and we want to show you, that Neos can fulfill these requirements easily. "Agency/Usergroup" sites are often feature driven and at some point experimental - Neos scores here as well.

If you've finished a TYPO3 Neos project by yourself - don't hesitate to write an email to neos [at] typo3 [dot] org to get it listed here as well. We are looking forward for your submissions!

properties.title: Code Sprint June 2014
properties.teaserText: The Neos/Flow team met for another code sprint at Technische Universiteit Eindhoven (TU/e) in the Netherlands leading up to the developer days. Three days were spent focussing on improving our tools, communication, discussing organizational matters, working on upcoming features and ended with finalizing the release of 1.1. The code sprint was medium sized with 13 participants in total.
properties.author: Aske Ertmann

properties.text:
The team has been evaluating a new project management tool called Jira for some time and work went into getting the necessary steps done for being able to use it. This is still an ongoing project and more news about that will come, but so far it’s looking very promising. Issues reported in the old tracker (forge) will still be seen, but it’s encouraged to report to the new system instead. You can use your typo3.org account to log in.

Additionally the team set up new emails for neos@typo3.org and flow@typo3.org that goes directly to a service desk in Jira that several team members have access to. This is done to avoid single points of failure and to speed up response times.

To ease the review process a new automatic coding guidelines cleanup task is in the making, which check the formal style of code reviews so the developers can focus on the important parts of reviewing. Current state is available here.

Improvements for the website were discussed and certain parts were updated, including the download instructions to make them more clear. Other technical improvements were also done. Additionally the review process was discussed and how to handle it in a good way, which will help new contributors and keeping the number of open reviews limited.

Realizing that the Flow website needs a caring hand the team planned to update the Flow website based on the Neos website and work has already begun to achieve that. If anybody would be interested in helping out with this project, please get in contact with us at flow@typo3.org.

One of the main topics of the code sprint was dealing with some of organizational challenges the team are facing. The release management and process was discussed to make the task more explicit, defining and describing the process as well as the responsibilities of the release manager. You can read more about it on the website. In addition to release management the team realised the feature development workflow had to be improved. This was realised after seeing the amount of work required for releasing 1.1, which took a lot longer than anticipated. From now on new features are not allowed to go into the core unless they are documented, provide tests and include release notes. This is done to prevent a pile up of work required for finalizing a release, additionally it should improve the completeness of features.

No code sprint without working on some interesting new features. At this code sprint that included finalising placeholder support for inline editing, global content constraints, translation of the user interface, content translation, a configuration module, tabbed inspector, inspector text area editor, improving TypoScript, fine-grained access controls and many other things. Most of which have been in progress for quite some time already and still have many things to do before they’re finishing, while others managed to be finished during the code sprint. More information about the upcoming features to come.

The team put a lot of effort into finish releasing 1.1 before the developer days and could happily announce the release about an hour prior to the opening of the developer days. This was important to the team since the team had a clear goal of improving adoption by the community. Thanks to Christian Müller for effectively taking on the role of release manager of this release. You can read more about the release in the release article.

properties.caption: The team celebrating releasing 1.1 just before the developer days.

properties.text: The team got together and discussed a proposed roadmap and selected Aske Ertmann as the release manager of the upcoming 1.2 release. More information about release dates and features coming.

Out of the 13 participants, the code sprint welcomed three new first timers, including Visay Keo from Web Essentials and Dominik Stankowski, member of the EAB, both joining from Cambodia. Thanks to all the participants and a special thanks to Rens Admiraal, Patrick Broens and TU/e for organising the sprint. More details can be found on wiki page.

In addition Bastian Waidelich and Andreas Förthner had their own little code sprint remotely at the same time focussing on fine-grained access control.

There are two code sprints in the planning for the third quarter of 2014. First one will be a smaller/short one in August (25th - 31st) planned to take place in northern Germany. If you’d like to participate please write to the mailing list.

Next up is a code sprint not to be missed. Following the success of the Copenhagen code sprint in 2012 which was held on a houseboat, the team is planning a repeating the formula of having a single location that accommodates work and living arrangements. This is much more effective and also cheaper compared to renting hotel rooms. The plan is to have a large number (16-32) of participants and to have a whole week, e.g. saturday till saturday. The location will probably be somewhere in Denmark, depending on the amount of participants either in a castle or a big summer house. The location will be sponsored and depending on how many participants the travel expenses will be fully reimbursed. The sprint is planned to take place in week 40 (29/9–3/10) and to plan the event the organizers need to know who plans to participate since finding a location depends a lot on how many participants. If you’d like to participate please respond to this doodle as soon as possible. As always the team welcomes new contributors to our code sprints with one simple rule being that you have some Neos experience and can mostly work on your own. Especially contributors with frontend knowledge (JavaScript, CSS) are needed. Hope to see you there

properties.title: Code Sprint October 2014
properties.teaserText:
Between 27th of september and 5th of october nearly 30 people met in Denmark at an amazing castle to work on TYPO3 Neos.

Participants from the United States, Cambodia, Russia and all over Europe worked on several parts of the content management system with the major goals to improve the user experience, add additional features and fix bugs.
properties.author: Berit Hlubek

properties.text: Aske Ertmann organized this sprint and found a wonderful location in the south of Denmark. Lungholm Castle is a manor from 15th century with wonderfully decorated rooms and a gigantic garden. Sleeping rooms with canopy beds, libraries with several comfortable couches and armchairs, a billiard room and a monorail dining room are only a few of the specialties this location had to offer. For the first time at a code sprint we had to organize and cook all meals on our own. This led to a good team atmosphere and it was easy to get to know everyone.

Several new contributors

Next to many team members and contributors, who already participated in previous Neos code sprints, we also had seven new contributors joining for the first time: Daniel Lienert (Germany), Dmitri Pisarev (Russia), Jonas Renggli (Switzerland), Kerstin Huppenbauer (Germany), Lars Nieuwenhuizen (The Netherlands), Philipp Hanebrink (Germany) and Steffen Frosch (Germany).

In the middle of the sprint Henjo Hoeksma (The Netherlands) organized a meeting with all of the first-time participants to gather some feedback on what we can do to lower the barriers that first-time contributors face. It was a fruitful meeting; We are now looking for solutions to the barriers identified in the meeting as well as already known challenges. For example, we will reorganize the contribution page on the website and work hard to improve the Neos documentation so that all of Neos is documented.

Finalizing Neos 1.2 Beta 1

One of the major tasks of the sprint was the finalization of TYPO3 Neos 1.2 Beta 1. Aske Ertmann (Denmark), Christopher Hlubek (Germany), Sebastian Helzle (Germany), Visay Keo (Cambodia), Dmitri, Jonas, Philipp, Daniel, Markus Goldbeck (Germany) and Christian Albrecht (Germany) worked on stability improvements, bugfixes and user experience optimizations for the next release. Robert Lemke (Germany) and Karsten Dambekalns (Germany) worked on finishing the content dimensions support with bugfixes and improvements. Their efforts included work on translatable URLs and site import and export which is now fully functional. Currently we plan to release Beta 1 within the next 2-3 weeks.

In addition to the general release topics, Dominique Feyer (Switzerland) also finalized some improvements of link handling. This means that with TYPO3 Neos 1.2, shortcut pages will include a link editor for the inspector and allow linking to internal pages, to assets and to external targets, instead of just to internal pages.

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.alternativeText: Working in one of the libraries
properties.title: Working in one of the libraries

properties.text:
Translations, ACLs and documentation

A big feature which was nearly finished is the translation of the TYPO3 Neos user interface. With this change it will be possible to translate all backend labels into every possible language. Henjo, Berti Golf (Germany), Sascha Nowak (Germany), Jonas and Christopher worked on the missing parts of this feature. We are using a online service for handling the translation, making it possible for everyone to help with translating to in his/her own language. The feature will be part of the 1.3 release, however the translation can start as soon as it’s finished in the development branch, so we have a multiple languages ready by the 1.3 release date.

Another commonly requested feature is access restrictions (ACLs). Andreas Förthner (Germany) and Rens Admiraal (The Netherlands) worked on the user interface and the test coverage for ACLs. Steps like the definition of privilege types are already done and nearly fully implemented. The status of the UI integration is somewhere around 80% done and one of the major tasks which are currently being worked on is the test coverage.

Jacob Floyd (USA) and Kerstin spend some time to improve documentation. Jacob is working on an editor guide and Kerstin finalized a frontend login plugin and afterwards started cookbook entries about that plugin and other topics like routing or content cache configuration.

Several discussions

During the sprint we also had a lot of time to discuss several topics. Two of those were image editing in Neos and planning for Neos 1.3.
Berit Hlubek (Germany) started the image editing discussion. It was mainly about what image edits are currently possible when editors add them to a website, and the ideas we have to make that better in future releases. Within the discussion we defined clear rules which will build the basis of the final concept. The goal will be to adjust the user interface and integrator options to provide a better user experience when creating responsive websites.

Robert initialized the discussion about TYPO3 Neos 1.3. We discussed different contribution barriers that might exist in the Neos project and brainstormed about several feature and improvement wishes for version 1.3. During the discussion we elected Robert as release manager for that version.

And more ...

Of course these are just some of the topics that we worked on during our code sprint. Some of the other things include:

  • Switch the currently used HTML editor (node type "HTML") to CodeMirror, this brings support for several other programming languages and not only HTML (Steffen)
  • XML Sitemap creation (Dominique)
  • Automated CGL Fixing within code reviews (Lienhart Woitok, Germany)
  • Making it possible to use Ember within you own backend module (Markus, Sascha)
  • Asset sharing between websites (Lars)
  • Development toolbar (Marc Neuhaus, Germany)
  • Automated node type creation based on schema.org (Dominique)
  • Update jira.typo3.org (Jacob)
  • Optimize neos.typo3.org website (Berit)
  • Everyone tried to work on moving tickets from Forge to Jira

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.alternativeText: Jonas, Steffen, Berti, Philipp, Markus, Sascha, Lienhart, Andi, Kerstin and Aske
properties.title: Jonas, Steffen, Berti, Philipp, Markus, Sascha, Lienhart, Andi, Kerstin and Aske

properties.text:
Thanks to all sponsors and participants

We want to thank every participant for this fruitful sprint, Aske for the organization and our great sponsors who made it possible to have a fully sponsored code sprint:

  • Axxess2 sponsored 400 €
  • internezzo AG sponsored 400 €
  • SimplyAdmire sponsored 500 €
  • networkteam sponsored 400 €
  • Olivier Dobberkau sponsored 100 €
  • TYPO3 Association paid travel costs and the location
If you are interested in taking part in a code sprint, sponsoring the next code sprint or helping out on whatever part of TYPO3 Neos, feel free to write us at neos [at] typo3 [dot] org.
